description: From Medieval Latin cultivātus, perfect passive participle of cultivō (“till, cultivate”), from cultīvus (“tilled”), from Latin cultus, perfect passive participle of colō (“till, cultivate”), which comes from earlier *quelō, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷel- (“to move; to turn (around)”). Cognates include Ancient Greek πέλω (pélō) and Sanskrit चरति (cárati). The same Proto-Indo-European root also gave Latin in-quil-īnus (“inhabitant”) and anculus (“servant”).

verbs.description: cultivate (third-person singular simple present cultivates, present participle cultivating, simple past and past participle cultivated)

examples: Most farmers in this region cultivate maize.

entries.meaning: (figurative) To nurture; to foster; to tend.
examples: They tried to cultivate an interest in learning among their students.

entries.meaning: To turn or stir soil in preparation for planting.
